section.title: Required topic tags
section.p: These DITA tags are required in a KMS topic:

dlentry.dd: The top level element for DITA topic documents. The <topic> tag has a required id attribute. See

The title of a document must appear as the first element. See You can create alternate titles for a document by adding them to the alt qlines document. For instructions on working with alternate q-lines, see . You can also use titles on sections of topics to create subheadings.

The container for elements that contain information about the topic; i.e., metadata. See Some of the elements in the prolog will be controlled by the KMS system. For example, the <created> element within the <critdates> element will contain the date that the topic was introduced into the system. If an editor changes that date while editing the topic, the system will revert to the previous value. However, elements such as <data> will retain the values entered by the editor.
<author> The name of the person who originally provided the content of the topic.
<critdates> A container element for elements containing date information about the topic. See
<created> Required to be the first element inside <critdates>. It can have three attributes that contain date information:
date the date of introduction of a topic into the system
golive the date on which the topic was first made visible to end users
expiry the date on which the topic should be reviewed. The <revised> element can also have an expiry attribute, and unlike the golive attribute which is also shared, I can't think of what an expiry on the <created> element would mean as opposed to an expiry on the <revised> element.
See
<revised> Records lifecycle dates for the topic. It can have three kinds of date attributes:
modified A required attribute; the date on which the topic was last changed
golive the date on which the revision was made visible to end users
expiry the date on which the revision should be checked for accuracy
See
<metadata> According to , elements inside the <metadata> element relate to the content of the topic; e.g., xtras, while elements in <prolog> but outside <metadata> pertain to the topic as a "content unit (such as the author or copyright), which are unrelated to the subject" of the topic. One allowed element in the <metadata> element is <audience>, but we are not going to use it here, as the KMS will control audience for whole topics by defining a key for the topic in the dita maps for the domains it belongs in.
<category> Any category that applies to the topic as a whole. You can apply multiple categories by adding additional <category> elements.
<keywords> Container element for keywords
<keyword> Terms that should return this topic when entered in searches; xtras, in KB parlance. You can put a numeric weighting in a base attribute.

The viewable contents of the DITA document. See The <body> element is only required insofar as it is a required container of any text nodes. The alt qline documents don't have any text other than the titles so they don't need <body> tags.

section.title: Semantic DITA tags
section.p: DITA provides a rich set of semantic tags that provides a superset of the semantics that we had with KBML. We'll be able to express nuances of meaning that we couldnt before. I describe them in terms of what KBML elements they replace.

row.entry: <code>, for text output by the computer
<code>, for text input by the user

section.title: Special purpose DITA tags
section.p: These elements serve special purposes in DITA beyond providing semantic tagging of content.

dd.p: DITA's general purpose element for creating cross-referencing links. See . The DITA standard recommends using higher-level linking structures built into ditamaps over hardcoding links at the topic level with <xref> elements. For the KB, the <xref> element will take the place of the <kba> KBML element, as well as the regular HTML <a> element. We will not use <xref>s to stand in for <kbh> elements, instead we will maintain these links in the reltable of the base ditamap. See the <reltable> section below for more information.

The <xref> element transcludes the text of the title of the link target similarly to the way the <kba> tag does. The <xref> element works differently in how to override the default title text: the <xref> element has no way of selecting an alternate qline as you can do with the qline attribute of the <xref> element. Instead, you can specify alternate text for the link by enclosing it within the <xref> element, as you would do with an HTML <a> element.

When creating <kba> style cross-referencing links to other KMS topics you should use the "keyref" attribute, which will allow us to use DITA keys to control access to documents. The href attribute can be used to create a fallback link in the case where the document is not available.

section.title: The audience attribute
section.p: The audience attribute serves the same purpose as the "who" attribute in KBML: filtering out the content within the tag having the "audience" attribute. The "audience" attribute can be placed in almost all DITA elements.

dlentry.dd:
We use topicrefs in ditamaps to represent relationships among topics, and to organize topics into domains. We put these topicrefs in two different ditamap structures to accomplish these two goals, and to make the system more modular we put these structures into separate maps and link the maps together:
in the reltable in base.ditamap The base ditamap contains the relationships among all topics in a kb as a whole. The reltable is structured with one row element, called relrow, per topic. Each relrow has three cell elements, called relcells. In the three relcells are one or more topicrefs. All the topicrefs should use keyref attributes containing the docid of the topic to allow DITA to resolve what topics are accessible. The three relcells contain, from left to right:
a topicref element for the source topic from which we're creating links
one topicref for each KB Ref of the source topic
one topicref for each hotitem of the source topic
in the ditamap file for the domain in which the topic belongs Each kb domain is represented by a ditmap that contains <topicref> elements for all the topics in that domain. Each topicref defines the dita key by which the topic will be referred to anywhere it is linked to. To render a certain domain you need to transform its corresponding ditamap with the DITA OT. The DOT will resolve the keys defined in the ditamap and maps linked to by that ditamap. By linking domains together with <mapref> elements in a tree structure we represent the KB domain hierarchy. For example, to add document anar to the all domain, you would add this line to domain-all.ditamap: <topicref keys="anaz" href="anaz.dita#anaz-dmm2"/>
